title: 110_hr2894
content: The Act may be cited as the "Star-Spangled Banner and War of 1812 Bicentennial Commemorative Coin Act". During the War of 1812, Francis Scott Key visited the British fleet to secure the release of Dr. William Beanes. Key was held overnight during the shelling of Fort McHenry but was delighted to see the American flag still flying after a 25-hour bombardment. He then began a poem to commemorate the occasion, which later became the "Star-Spangled Banner". In 1916, President Woodrow Wilson ordered the "Star-Spangled Banner" to be played at military and naval occasions. In 1931, it became our National Anthem. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint $1 silver coins in commemoration of the bicentennial of the Star-Spangled Banner and the War of 1812. The coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall symbolize the War of 1812, specifically the Battle for Fort McHenry. Each coin will feature a value designation, the year "2012", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with relevant commissions. Each coin will feature a value designation, the year "2012", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with relevant commissions, including the Commission of Fine Arts and the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a designated Mint facility during the calendar year beginning on January 1, 2012. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. All sales of coins issued under this Act will include a $10 surcharge per coin, with the surcharges going to the Maryland War of 1812 Bicentennial Commission for supporting bicentennial activities related to the War of 1812. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct audits. The Comptroller General of the United States has the right to audit the Maryland War of 1812 Bicentennial Commission's expenditures. No surcharge can be included for issuing coins if it exceeds the annual commemorative coin program limit. The Secretary of the Treasury may provide guidance for this limitation. The House of Representatives passed the document on May 15, 2008, as attested by LORRAINE C. MILLER, Clerk.
